comments.commentBody:
Isn't there a difference between a snack and a treat? Isn't a snack something relatively healthful and maybe even necessary, like eating a carb/protein if there is going to be a long stretch between meals?

And a treat is something fun, maybe a reward, maybe you even know it's bad for you, but hey once in awhile it's necessary, and how else are you going to learn to manage what you eat?
Just read Scott Brown's victory speech. What a petty little man he is.

You HAVE to look at the map. I came up with two obvious questions; was there voter commuting, and did TV out of Boston and Hartford have a big influence? I HIGHLY recommend viewing a road map. Please keep the county results map on the front page. More important, please answer if you know, is Massachusetts voter registration state-wide or only by county? Please post a reply.
Perhaps all states need state-wide voter databases cross-checking more than new voting machines. I have no axe to grind, I find all politicians are unresponsive. The map just showed me like a photo shows you folks. Thanks for all the coverage and posting my comments, pat

The taking back of Congress by the people has begun. In Mass. and in a seat held by a Kennedy for 58 years, no less. Congrats Senator Brown.
287 days to go for the Democrat's Waterloo. Just 287 days, but who's counting?

Add another NO to the party of NOs. It seems Americans have very short memory and we won't even talk about the attention span.

No wonder the country is going down. God help us.

The Democrats in the Congress chose to spend their time larding up the healthcare legislation with their pet projects that did little to address the voters' concerns with claim denials, cancellation of coverage, use of pre-existing conditions to refuse coverage, the buying of Congress by Pharma and the health insurance companies.

The current healthcare bill allegedly being resolved by the Democrats in the House and Senate includes the worst of many options, solves too few of the problems, and is being welcomed by both the pharmaceutical industry and and the health insurance insurance industry.

In short, they sank their own rubber duck when they were the only ones in the bath tub.

In the meantime, the Republicans gleefully stated that America has the best, if not by far the most expensive, healthcare in the world for 80% of the population. Apparently 40 - 50 million people with no healthcare coverage is a non-event to Republicans.

The election results in Massachussetts appear to be a reaction against healthcare. I believe it is a bigger reaction (similar to that of 2006 and 2008) against the incumbents of both parties. The electorate is tired of the insults and rock throwing by people that have been sent to discuss, evaluate, and legislate in the name of the people, not the contributors and lobbyists.

When Hillary Clinton led the healthcare reform effort in '93, and lost, she confessed that her biggest error was doing it behind closed doors and presenting it as all or nothing. The result was nothing. Obama, Reid and Pelosi are doing it even more poorly than Hillary did; they are doing it behind closed doors, cutting incomprehensible deals, buying votes, delaying benefits, and fudging the numbers to make it seem revenue neutral. No one is fooled by these gyrations.

Scott Brown was victorious because he stood pat and called them out on it. Is it possible that they are so close to the action that they can't see what an outrageous, short sighted, unmanagable, mish-mash of nonsense they have put together? Or are they so intent in being in the history books as the authors of universal healthcare that their ego's are in the way?

Brown said it best. We CAN do better. Start from scratch and get it right, or fail to ram it through and be unceremoniously retired from the house and senate.

The sea is angry, my friends......

Well, the Democrats have done it again, folks! It's not easy to snatch defeat from the party that was virtually dead only months ago, but they did it! You have to give them credit for their monumental stupidity!

MA voters have universal health care -- voted to deny it to rest of U.S.  MA Brownie for waterboarding, opposes womens' rights.  Bush/Cheney Depression, here we come!  Get your Wal-Mart greeter contractor job on, Townies!
this is an outsider's view, but to me it looks like anti-Obama racism.

Had Martha Coakley not run a horrible campaign this model-clown of false promises would have never won. Now the MA voters can watch this junior Senator join in the party of NO - no fresh and innovative ideas, no help for anyone but the wealthy, and a bunch of arrogant politicians with 1st rate healthcare while 40MM Amercans continue to suffer and some even die for lack of healthcare.

Third Party candidate-can't you folks do the math? But that is not really so amazing for what is really amazing is how your prop ups of EMK come out with touches of attack built into to them as though he lost tonight and not whats-her-name.
It's all over folks. This stupid country deserves everything that's soon coming to it...  flames and ash.

comments.userLocation: NYC but on Cape Cod right now
comments.commentBody:
I'm very sorry to see that Scott Brown won the election. Apparently he won really big on the Cape and Islands. Driving around the Cape the past week made it very clear how much support Brown had in this area as yard signs for him outnumbered those for Coakley. Even before the election there were a lot of people in this area who did not think much of Coakley. And her ads (terrible) did very little to help her.

Some people are saying that this election is a referendum on Obama and on healthcare. That may be some of it. Healthcare has been very divisive and misrepresented. I can see dissatisfaction with the Democrats as a whole playing a part. Even with a 60 person majority, the Democrats have been unable to pass any significant legislation. And ever measure seems to get watered down and bunged up until it is unrecognizable.

Still, one election for one Senate seat does not a referendum make. And we should not over push this idea.

I very much supported President Obama and still support many of his initiatives. I am an Independent and a progressive liberal. But the Democrats deserve the loss in Massachusetts.
1) When they "bought-off" Ben Nelson of Nebraska with that disgraceful deal to have the government fund his states additional Medicaid costs, they doomed their fate; 2) Martha Coakley was a very weak candidate who disappeared from the campaign trail from December 15 to January 9 - GIVE US A BREAK and 3) they took Massachusetts for granting. TIME TO WAKE UP!

Brutal!!

Debt is important factor? Um, guess what is far and away the most expensive portion of the entire deficit? - WAR! Oh, and let's go over whom has gone to war? Geez, what a joke people, really. We here in America are silly funny....we help Iraq fight Iran in the 8 year war, we attack Iran in 1988, we give information to Saddam to use nerve gas on Iran, then we turn around and attack Iraq. - Oh, and don't even get me started on how we propped up Iran for the previous 40 years, when the Teddy Roosevelt's own grandson Kermit Roosevelt (research him, and see what very awesome things he did for America. you know, like engineer a coup in 1953 against the DEMOCRATICALLY voted in Prime Minister, whom did not share the same goals as America, so they put the prior Shah back in power, oh, and then they helped create a Big Brother state police called the Savak...all in the name of "democracy") Awesome. All for what? Oil. Love it. Why? So we can drive our Fat Hummer H3's to go pick up Billy from soccer practice in suburban America.

OIL

OIL

OIL = War = the costliest portion of our national debt, and it is not even close

I wonder who we are going to attack and say they are "evil" next, I bet you that country above us, we totally could take them!

Watching the news from Massachusetts, and around this country, I am afraid for our nation. There is a great chance that on January 20, 2012, Sarah Palin will be inaugurated President of the United States. And if you think there cannot be a repeat of Florida 2000 again, get real. Everything that happened then can happen again, and a lot worse, too.

Palin was behind Barack Obama 20 points last summer. Now she is behind him 6 points. She is the favorite of conservatives, the dominant faction in the Republican Party. Now she has a program on Fox. There can be little doubt that she will be the Republican nominee in 2012.

Seeing the complaints by so many liberals, and indeed the hard attacks on Obama by so many liberals, I am mystified. Do you really think he is the problem? Have you looked at Glen Beck lately? Have you looked at the “tea baggers” lately? They are extreme, vicious, violent, and growing.

Political ideology, especially in its most extreme form, and advocated with great fervor, is a lot like addiction. It’s irrational, and it cannot be addressed by rational argument. It’s certainly an obsession to those who hold it. As Morris Berman said, “An idea is something you have; an ideology is something that has you.” The problem is always some other group. The nation is threatened by enemies, within and without. Blame is always laid on others. Facts are disputed, distorted or denied to suit the agenda of the ideologue. (That is called denial.) The world abounds with conspiracies, all aimed against the ideology. No respect is shown for anyone whose viewpoint differs.

I thought, after the Bush administration, the war in Iraq, starting with falsified evidence, over 100,000 killed, and a trillion dollars wasted, and the events of last fall, when our economy almost collapsed, that American had “hit bottom” on the American conservative movement and the political right. I thought we had learned that we had to pay attention to reality, to facts, that we could not pray our way out of problems, that the world out there is not created by our desires, and that we do not create reality by our actions (as one member of the Bush administration said).

I was wrong.

Glen Beck advocates a fascist program. He has stated explicitly that he wants, “to bring us all back to the place we were on September 12, 2001. The day after America was attacked we were not obsessed with Red States, Blue States or political parties. We were united as Americans, standing together to protect the greatest nation ever created.” Bush had 91% approval ratings just after 9/11, but that does not mean that we as a nation had decided to stop thinking.

The nation united as one, without differences, is the essence of fascism. It is the fascist ideology in a nutshell. It’s inherent in the fascist symbol, the fasces, which derives from the Roman Empire. Pieces of wood were bundled together as one, to strengthen the bundle and hold an axe, for use as a weapon. Hitler and Mussolini were quite clear on this point.

The ideologue will say or do anything to advance his ideology. He or she will attack the opposition by any means available. So, we liberals are “not real Americans.” We are “traitors.” “Loyal to other countries.” We are too “intellectual,” meaning that we don’t fit in with the real America. In America today, we have people who seriously believe that Obama was not born in America, that he is a Muslim, or that he sides with other nations against our own.

Another tactic that extremists use is to project their worst traits onto others. Hence you see Glen Beck’s show running newsreels of the Third Reich, or posters of Obama with a Hitler mustache.

Robert O. Paxton wrote persuasively and with great erudition about fascism in his book, “The Anatomy of Fascism”:

“Feelings propel fascism more than thought does. We might call them mobilizing passions, since they function in fascist movements to recruit followers and in fascist regimes to “weld” the fascist “tribe” to its leader) The following mobilizing passions are present in fascisms, though they may sometimes be articulated only implicitly:
lol, Obama tweeting the SOTU! love it

Thank God and the great people of the state of Massachusetts for what they have done for our nation. Thank you so much Massachusetts. We will replace Mary Landreau ASAP. Thank you again, you are wonderful.

It's ironic that today I found out that my best friend will be losing his health insurance. He has MS, and is in the process of being treated for a flair up of his symtoms. It's unfathomable to me that we allow people to suffer and die of perfectly treatable illnesses. At this moment I am overwhelmed with grief and anger about what is happening to our government. They are monsters, all of them - the Republicans. Utterly despicable human beings.

Enjoy your victory Mr. Brown while other people die unnecessarily and the lives around of those around them are completely destroyed.

End of any chance of to pass anything that will help the middle class. Now the Republicans can
say NO to everything and block it too.

Remember the song "Only the Beginning" ALL candidates in both parties running for re-election in the mid terms should take note. The Brown victory in MA is the intitial message sent by the American people to Washington.The will of the people will prevail and every "Agenda" being rammed down our throat carries a high price.Reform needs to be made by "CHANGE"ing our federal laws and invoke term limits on the House and Senate.

Thank heavens for Brown.  All the folk driving round in Axis Powers motor vehicles transferring American wealth to the exporting nations...and yet expecting more and more from the US government.  Socialists might promise "free" heath but what about the waiting times!

This was a hard fought campaign which tested the resources and communication skills of the Tea Party Movement.  I'm proud of everyone in the on-line community (and on Twitter) who got the word out that Scott Brown could win and how to donate money to his campaign on-line.  In victory, I think it is a good idea to be gentle with our foes.  After all, Brown's success is due - in large measure - to the clear thinking of Democrats, Independents, and Moderates who saw truth in his ideas and issues.
Bring in the clowns, for they have chosen (poorly) once again!
